reviewText: It's been a long time coming, but now Star Trek fans can FINALLY complete their collection of 23rd century adventures of the starship Enterprise.  I'm pleased that Paramount didn't take the quick & easy route with this series.  There were rumors that this would just be a "bare bones" set, with just the episodes and no extras.  But Paramount did the right thing, and has given us a collection that will sit proudly beside the original series DVD collections (even the packaging mirrors those earlier releases).Of the bonus features, "Drawing the Final Frontier" is really the only one of note.  It's a 24-minute documentary on the making of the animated series.  One minor complaint: The creators spend way too much time trying to justify the show as "real" Star Trek.  This is an age-old, and (in my opinion) ridiculous argument among Trek fans.  Gene Roddenberry was involved with the series.  It featured almost all the regular cast.  It was written by original series veterans, as well as other noteworthy science fiction writers.  How could it NOT be considered "real" Trek?There's a well-intentioned, but brief and poorly designed feature on continuity withing the Trek universe.  Trust me, you'll watch it once and probably never again.  The same goes for the text-only segment on the show's history.  Still, I appreciate that time was taken to create ANY supplemental material for this set.As for the show itself. . .it's a hard lesson of growing up: Nostalgia ain't what it used to be.  BUT, looking at the show from an adult standpoint, it's easy to appreciate the quality writing (most of the time) and the fact that care was taken to be true to the original series.  The voice work is all fine, with the versatile James Doohan providing several additional character voices.  Sadly, the animation is sub-par, even for an early 70's production.  This is particularly apparent in the frequent close-up shots of characters, whose faces barely move.Still, if you're a Star Trek fan, there's no question that you have to have the animated series.  With a little imagination (which we still had to use back in the seventies and is virtually unknown in the age of CGI), you can imagine you're watching a "lost" fourth season of the original series.
summary: A forgotten piece of Trek history finally gets its due

Unfortunately, with the exception of a handful of episodes (Yesteryear comes to mind), these animated episodes are more in line with the cheesier aspects of Trek.  The animation is barely there most of the time, and the scripts lean toward the fantastic more than the humanistic elements. This is one cartoon that does not insult its viewers.An attention span is required.A love for the characters is recommended.

reviewText: I did not see "Star Trek: The Animated Series", during its original broadcast run on NBC, but I do remember seeing a few episodes as they were shown on local channels some years afterward.  Having become a fan of "Star Trek" as a teenager, it made sense for me to pick up this Emmy Award-winning series once it became available on DVD, and it was money well spent.TAS has the same look and feel of other animated series of the era.  But the stories have some heft.  That's due, in part, to D.C. Fontana being on board to help with the stories.  She helped keep the stories true to the universe of The Original Series, including episodes involving old favorites Harry Mudd and the Tribbles.  TAS could also go where the crew of the Enterprise couldn't go in live-action, and that is to worlds that could be explored with more freedom and imagination.  And in one particular episode, Lieutenant Uhura (voiced by the talented and gorgeous Nichelle Nichols) actually has to take command of the Enterprise in a crisis situation!Fans of "Star Trek" will love hearing the familiar voices of William Shatner, DeForest Kelley and Leonard Nimoy, and seeing the faithful Enterprise recreated in animated form.  And fans of animation will enjoy the style that Filmation made with this show and others, including the legendary "Fat Albert".  The animation featurette included in the package features producer Lou Scheimer, who along with the late Norm Prescott brought TAS to television.TAS is definitely a set to add to the collection.  It is a landmark in television history and a wonderful tribute to one of the most popular live-action series of all time.

reviewText: The first time I saw this complete DVD set was in 2007. I enjoyed it then and I enjoyed it in 2012-2013. For instance, Arax was a nice addition even if Chekov had to be cast off due to budgetry problems.This leads me to my criticism of the show. The low budget did not allow for many new voice actors. Thus the cast members of the show had to do double and triple duty. Normaly this is not a problem. In animation shows this is done quite often. Not only that, but I felt the ending was totally unrealistic. I mean, I can see Commodore Robert April wanting to use the transporters to bring the crew back to their "normal" static ages, but I found it incredible that a 75-year-old man who'd been reduced in age by 30-35 physiological years would want to return to his actual chronological age! He insists on returning to his age because he'd already "lived his life and did not feel the need to live it again." That's a paraphrase, but I find it unbelievable.Check out "Beyond the Farthest Star", "Yesteryear", "The Lorelei Signal", "The Survivor", "The Slaver Weapon", and "The Jihad". Each of these episodes in and of themselves could have been made into hour long live action episodes, and very well may have had Star Trek continued into a fourth season. What we missed in live action we received in animation. I'm thankful for that! I liked "The Lorelei Signal"! What man wouldn't want to be stranded on a planet with gorgeous women (Minus The Extreme Ageing Put Upon Us Helpless Lads By Those Lovely Lasses!)While the animation is dated by today's standards (Although It Did Have Some Interesting Limited Rotoscoping Which Added To Realism), it's the storylines that will capture your imagination. reviewText: This set has been a long time coming, not the least bit thanks to the legal morass surrounding the shutdown of Filmation (the actual producers of the animated Star Trek) and a mysterious directive from Gene Roddenberry concerning the status of the series compared to its live action progenitor.  That matter is still debated today, with various conspiracy theories and suspected villains, all conniving to keep TAS buried.  Well, no more, it's now out on a thoroughly official DVD set, with plenty of extras (including another few cents' worth regarding whether or not TAS can be considered canon).Overall, it's a well-produced presentation of a largely forgotten part of Star Trek lore.  There are a few minor oddities, like an apparent, and completely unnecessary "fix" of the background in "The Time Trap", from red to black (it's a pocket universe; who says it has to be black?).  Besides, that only begs the question of why they felt the need to change that but not fix the real errors, like characters in the wrong color uniforms or sporting the wrong rank stripes.In any case, now all of televised Star Trek is out on video, with the minor exception of network promos and Nimoy's in-costume cameo on "The Carol Burnett Show" in a skit about a frantic mother needing the help of Dr. Spock.All in all, it's a good thing (with apologies to Martha Stewart).

reviewText: After NBC cancelled the original Star Trek series in 1969 for its second time, it seemed doubtful that the voyages of the Starship Enterprise would resume again until Filmation resurrected the original cast (with the notable exception of Walter Koenig) on September 8, 1973 for the Animated Series. William Shatner, Leonard Nimoy, DeForest Kelly, James Doohan, Nichelle Nichols, George Takei and Majel Barrett lent their vocal talents to bring their familiar characters back to the small screen in addition to a few new bridge officers: Lt. Arex, a three-armed and legged alien of the Edo species voiced by James Doohan, and Lt. M'Ress a Caitian cat-woman with Majel Barrett purring her alluring voice. With most of the original crew onboard, the five-year mission would boldly go on for at least 22 more episodes of continuing missions. While it is generally regarded as non-canon among Trekkies (even Gene Rodenberry himself rejected the notion that TAS was canon and even the Stardates are inconsistent with those established in the original series) the animated series still contributed some reverent facts to the legacy of the enduring franchise including the revelation of Captain James T. Kirk's middle name as 'Tiberius' and the establishment of the first holodeck (known as the 'Rec Room') in the episode "The Practical Joker" which would serve as an important narrative device for The Next Generation. Walter Koenig would still contribute to the series as a writer for the episode "The Infinite Vulcan" and alumnus D.C. Fontana would write the stand-out episode "Yesteryear" in which Spock travels through the Guardian of Forever from the highly acclaimed Original Series episode "City on the Edge of Forever" and has to mentor his childhood self as an alienated half-human, half-Vulcan outcast on his home planet Vulcan.Star Trek: TAS was one of Filmation's finest achievements along with The New Adventures of Flash Gordon and both shows shared the same theatrical quality animation with director Hal Sutherland at the helm of both shows. Despite budgetary constraints requiring some stock shots to be recycled, and occassional continuity errors in animation plates and erratic stories, the series managed to preserve the production design and spirit of the original series quite faithfully. I fondly remember most of all the stock Filmation background music by Jeff Michael and Yvette Blais which was looped throughout the series and recycled in several Filmation productions afterward including Ark II, Space Academy, Jason of Star Command and Tarzan. To this day, I can still hear that incidental music playing in my head after some 30 years and I would hope that someone will eventually release the soundtrack on CD. With the soundtrack being remastered in Dolby Digital 5.1 for the DVD release, it would seem logical that the original unmixed production tracks might possibly still exist for them to release the isolated music score and would serve not just as a piece of forgotten Trek memorabillia to merchandise but also a reference of nostalgic source cues from the Filmation music library (Lou Scheimer, are you listening?).To coincide with the television broadcast of Star Trek: TAS in 1974, Mego Toy Corporation introduced a successful series of 8-inch action figures and a vinyl U.S.S. Enterprise bridge playset featuring a spinning Transporter chamber to make action figures "dematerialize." Fascinating.Star Trek: The Animated Series beams onto DVD for the first time on November 21, 2006 and feature all 22 episodes remastered in high definition, 2 featurettes "Drawn to the Final Frontier - The Making of Star Trek: The Animated Series" and "What's the Star Trek Connection?," 3 episode commentaries by writers David Wise and David Gerrold, interviews and commentaries with Filmation producer Lou Scheimer, director Hal Sutherland and writer Dorothy Fontana, photo gallery, text commentary by Michael and Denise Okuda on episodes "Yesteryear" "The Eye of the Beholder" and "The Counter-Clock Incident," stoyboards, wallpaper and AIM icons, and much more!These are the Animated voyages of the Starship Enterprise:Season 1 (1973-1974)101 "Beyond the Farthest Star"102 "Yesteryear"103 "One of Our Planets is Missing"104 "The Lorelei Signal"105 "More Tribbles, More Troubles"106 "The Survivor"107 "The Infinite Vulcan"108 "The Magicks of Megas-tu"109 "Once Upon a Planet"110 "Mudd's Passion"111 "The Terratin Incident"112 "The Time Trap"113 "The Ambergris Element"114 "The Slaver Weapon"115 "The Eye of the Beholder"116 "The Jihad"Season 2 (1974)201 "The Pirates of Orion"202 "Bem"203 "The Practical Joker"204 "Albatross"205 "How Sharper Than a Serpent's Tooth"206 "The Counter-Clock Incident"

reviewText: The animated Star Trek holds a unique--if unenviable--position in the Trek pantheon in that Paramount ignored and downplayed it so extensively over the years that many fans, especially younger ones, were unaware it even existed. Hopefully, tomorrow's DVD release will help remedy that, because TAS deserves to be recognized as a legitimate part of the phenomenon that is Star Trek.Despite it's being animated and having originally aired as part of NBC's Saturday morning lineup, the animated Trek is anything but typical kiddie fare. My understanding is that when Gene Roddenberry originally licensed the concept to Filmation, it was conceived as a prime time animated series--a continuation of the original live action series in a new medium that could be enjoyed by both children and adults. Unfortunately, NBC didn't share their vision. This was some 15 years before The Simpsons legitimized the concept of animation in prime time.To that end, the folks at Filmation secured the talents of most of the original cast, as well as many of the writers from the original series. Great pains were also taken to draw the characters so they closely resembled the actors who voiced them, and to re-create the overall visual style of the original show. Unfortunately, the animated Star Trek came along at a time when the cost of full 24-frames-per-second animation had escalated tremendously and computer technology was still too primitive to be viable for use in animation, a condition that would remain unchanged for more than a decade. For this reason, animation during the '70s and well into the '80s was done in a more limited form, usually 10-16 frames per second. Still, the animated Trek manages to capture much of the fun and excitement of the original.Over the years, the idea of 're-animating' the animated series by mating the original audio to new CGI animation has been bandied about, and while I initially though it would be a good idea, the recent digital enhancements on the original series have me re-thinking that position. Just because you can do something doesn't always mean you should. That said, the show is quite enjoyable and holds up well after more than 30 years if judged on its own merits instead of on the shortcomings of the era in which it was made.
summary: The "forgotten voyages" finally beam onto DVD

reviewText: The opening segment of Star Trek, always eludes to the Enterprise's 5 year mission, yet the Classic Series only ran 3.  For 2 seasons on Saturdays mornings on NBC (the network that originally brought us Classic Trek) starting in the fall of 1973 we got to see "the rest of the story" in these 22 cartoons.  All the original cast is back save for Walter Koenig who had other commitments (but he did write one episode).  Nichelle Nichols (Uhura), Majel Barrett (Chapel), George Takei (Sulu) and James Doohan (Scotty) also supply supplemental voices for other crewmembers, aliens and others.  4 episodes are actually sequels to Classic Episodes "Once Upon A Planet" (from "Shore Leave"), "Yesteryear" (indirectly from "The City On The Edge Of Forever"), "Mudd's Passion" ("Mudd's Women" and "I, Mudd") and "More Tribbles, More Troubles" (from "The Trouble With Tribbles" with the latter 2 featuring the voices of the actors that made those episoodes favorites (Roger Carmel and Stanley Adams respectively).  This set shows all 22 episodes in order of their Original airdate on NBC and uncut (I never realized my taped copies from SciFi were cut til my disc set arrived yesterday).  The only glitch I found in the set, is that description of "Yesteryear" in the companion booklet refers to Spock as "Dr. Spock" rather than "Mr. Spock" (perhaps the author of the booklet was having a baby at the time?).  Except for that, definitely worth the purchase.
summary: The Rest Of The Historic "5 Year" Mission

reviewText: What's the next best thing when you don't have the "reel"-life characters of your favourite series to view anymore? What needs to be pointed out though is that the quality of the animation is very rudimentary and shows us just how far animation has come since the 70's to today what with CGI and so forth.  If you are interested in this package for the quality of the animation, you will be severely disappointed.  If it's the quality of the stories that you are interested in, then this is for you.  Other pluses include the very attractive plastic packaging that resembles somewhat a tricorder.  What impressed me most about this whole package other than the good stories is the very, very good sound quality.  The Dolby Digital 5.1 surround sound is excellent which is a shame in that it has to go together with the poor animation.  I wonder if it is possible to modernise the whole thing by keeping the soundtrack but doing a modern, CGI version of the animation? reviewText: Amidst great protest from hardboiled fans, the original Star Trek was cancelled in 1969. To partly assuage these loyalists, Star Trek: The Animated Series was created in 1973. While I wasn't around then for the original airings of the cartoon Star Trek, I've had a chance to check them out on various reruns. Now, I'm not a Star Trek purist, so I'm not passionate either way about  whether Star Trek: TAS should count in the official continuity (for what it's worth, I think it counts; Gene Roddenberry begs to differ, so I guess I lose). But what I do care about are good stories told in an entertaining way. And, make no mistake, these are well-told stories, in spite of the inconsistent star dates, stock footage, and continuity errors.Originally, George Takei and Nichelle Nichols weren't slated to be part of the voice cast, until Leonard Nimoy stepped in and protested. In the end, all but one regular cast member (Walter Koenig) of the original live action show signed on, effectively lending their voice talents. James Doohan and Majel Barrett, in fact, not only voiced Scotty and Nurse Chapel - as well as new crew members Arex and M'Ress - respectively, but also other various guest characters and extras. For fans of Sarek, Mark Lenard guest starred as Spock's dad in the time travel episode "Yesteryear."The Filmation Company, for the ancient, primitive cartoon-crafting 1970s, did a decent job animating the further exploits of Kirk, Spock, McCoy, and all. In fact, the world of animation provided the writers the freedom to introduce more aliens and more detailed alien vistas that would've been way beyond the budget of a live action series. Admittedly, it was fun when the writers occasionally dipped to the well of the live action show episodes. Bringing back Harry Mudd, The Guardian of Forever, and tribbles strongly reinforced the show's ties to the parent series.Probably the best thing that Star Trek: TAS accomplished was not dumbing down the stories. They could've as easily reduced the characters to typical weapon-toting action heroes ala Flash Gordon and Buck Rogers. Instead, we were treated to insightful episodes which contained adult sensibilities and sensitive morality plays, thus continuing the trend pioneered by the original show. The producers must've known that the adult concepts and heady storylines will sail over the heads of the targeted young audience. Certainly, the show's sophistication was a factor in its early demise. The series ran from 1973 to 1974, with only 22 episodes. But, never mind. Today, we reap the benefits of the show's staying true to the Star Trek spirit and to Gene Roddenberry (in spite of his refusal to ackowledge the show).

reviewText: First of all, I have not seen the final six episodes (the 2nd season) of TAS yet. I am currently digesting the first season(episodes 1-16). As a 10 year old in '73, I found the animation really lousy, even for 1973 so I didn't watch it back then. Looney Tunes, The Pink Panther, and Walt Disney were the ones I enjoyed (still do). And even though they were all high-budget theatrical releases, so much of television animation at the time was superior to TAS. Just look at Scooby Doo. That animation was so much better and it was also four years older than TAS. Filmation did it on the cheap slide just as they always did. As an adult, I can now sit down and enjoy the series as if I am watching a new series of TOS. As a huge fan of TOS in the 70s, I have come to my own conclusions in the 21st century of what makes TOS so special.The first thing about TAS is Roddenberry's little input. That's a plus! Roddenberry was pushed out (or shall we say, pushed up) into an upper office following the second season of TAS. He again was booted out by Meyer and et.al. at the beginning of production of Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan in 1981. So While Roddenberry had very little to do with TAS, TAS benefitted from someone, I feel, was the backbone of the whole TOS and TAS: Dorothy Fontana. Hey...when it comes to GOOD science fiction, what is the most important thing? Special effects? Please. Good acting? That's crucial. A huge budget? Not really. THE MOST IMPORTANT THING IN GOOD SCIENCE FICTION IS THE WRITING! Without good writing, you have nothing!So...while the animation on TAS kind of stinks, some of the writing is absolutely superb. And with D.C. in charge of stories, you have the makings for an enjoyable series.1st Season (1-5 stars, 5 stars being excellent) (reviewed in production order)01 - More Tribbles, More Troubles **  Too much valuable screen time rehashing the TOS episode. And like a producer of TOS said, "Star Trek isn't a comedy"02 - The Infinite Vulcan **  Written by Walter Koenig. This is where Koenig began his writing career. I understand he has become quite a prolific writer. Well...I hope he has learned a lot since he penned this.03 - Yesteryear *****  I am in total agreement with the majority of those who worked on TAS that this is the definitive episode of this series. It has a lesson to teach...a lesson which every child, every human being, has to deal with: Loss.  And notice how Fontana didn't spend any time rehashing the existence of The Guardian of Forever as David Gerrold did rehashing the tribble episode.04 - Beyond the Farthest Star  ****  Very well done. Another lesson to be learned in this episode: Loneliness transcends the human condition.05 - The Survivor  **  A sort of rehash of the whole Dr. Corby issue from TOS. Some interesting scenes, but a yawner.06 - The Lorelei Signal  ***  An interesting concept. Women grow strong by draining the strength of men. The lack of more needed voices really hurts this episode.07 - One of Our Planets Is Missing  ***  Similar in plot to TOS' "Operation Annihilate", I find the animation in this episode very well done. And Spock's mind-meld with the entity is certainly a highlight.08 - Mudd's Passion  **  Complete rehash of Mudd's women. Yes, some things are changed, but the true essence of good science fiction is ORIGINALITY!09 - The Magicks of Megas-Tu  *  The background of this episode is interesting. The original story was about God. But we can't have God. He's against the law. So let's change it to the Devil. And let's put horns on his head and a man's torso and a goat's legs and feet. All we are missing is a pitch fork. Wow...the ancient medieval god Pan on Star Trek. The worst science fiction I have ever seen. A total waste of time.10 - The Time Trap  ***  I found it odd that one starship couldn't escape the vortex but two in tandem working together could. Story is somewhat of a rehash of "Errand of Mercy" from TOS...be nice little boys and girls. Enjoyable episode.11 - The Slaver Weapon  **  This is somewhat of a strange episode. Only Spock, Uhura, and Sulu involved against the aliens. Also some bloopers (Sulu introducing the landing party? There is something called protocol). The weapon is capable of what looks and sounds like a device that can trigger an atomic explosion at a distance (let's hope it's a long distance). In the 23rd century, an overloaded phaser can do that. I found it quite dull.12 - The Ambergris Element  **  Probably the most violent episode of the first season. One particular scene shows Kirk and Spock left at the shore, obviously suffocating, to die. And only due to the alertness of a  "red shirt" are they saved from what looks like cold blooded murder.13 - The Jihad  **  I tried to find something in this episode redeeming and I can't. Plus, I realize the show was only twenty five minutes long, but there is no way Kirk could deduce sabotage with the few facts he had. Boring.14 - The Terratin Incident  ***  Very interesting plot here. A colony so small that they must "attack" the enterprise in order to get the crew's attention so that the attackers can be saved. Very fine episode.15 - The Eye of the Beholder  ****  Another excellent episode. Just because something is ugly, or we don't understand it, doesn't mean it is bad. Certainly a favorite episode of mine.16 - Once Upon a Planet  **  Another rehash of a TOS episode. If you can't come up with something original for science fiction, find another way to make a living.After I check out the second season (the final six episodes), I shall review them. I believe any Star Trek fan will enjoy the TAS. I don't feel I missed out on anything by missing the original broadcasts 40 years ago. But then again, I'm somewhat of a purist. With the exception of Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan, I have never liked the films and I have never seen TNG, VOY, or any of the others either. And I still don't feel like I have missed out on anything.
summary: Very Interesting Show But Limited Animation Makes the Series an Unknown to Many

reviewText: Without a doubt, "Star Trek The Animated Series" was one of the finest animated television series ever created for television, giving the original version of "Star Trek" an additional year of televised episodes. Much to my amazement, the stories still hold up quite well for most of the episodes, with my favorite one being the classic "Yesteryear" (written by original series writer and producer D. C. Fontana), since the animated series was blessed with exceptional acting from the original cast (with the notable exception of Walter Koenig, though he did contribute the script to another fine episode, "Infinite Vulcan") and superb writing from original series writers like Samuel Peeples ("Beyond the Farthest Star", David Gerrold ("More Tribbles, More Troubles") and D. C. Fontana. Other favorite episodes include Larry Niven's "The Slaver Weapon" (In which he borrows his Kzinti, introducing them to the "Star Trek" universe), "The Time Trap", "The Jihad" and "Mudd's Passion". I'm not going to delve once more into the ongoing arguments as to whether or not the animated series is a canonical televised addition to the original series, or whether the Great Bird of the Galaxy (Gene Roddenberry) regarded it as part of official "Star Trek" canon, except to note that as former diehard fan of "Star Trek" - but also as a fan of fine science fiction television - that this animated series did a superb job in carrying on both the artistic and philosophical aspects of the original series' legacy. Last, but not least, this DVD collection includes insightful audio commentary from David Gerrold and Denise and Michael Okuda for several episodes.

reviewText: the cartoon version of Star Trek was always easy to overlook simply because animation itself was so readily dismissed as "kid's stuff" for so long. you'd think in this age, when cartoons are slightly more "acceptible" as an adult guilty pleasure, it would manage to build up some more cred. maybe it has, but it still has a ways to go.there are admittedly limitations that (albeit only just barely) keep it from recreating the grandeur of it's live-action ancestor. most obviously the reduction from an hour to a half-hour, meaning it's stories couldn't be quite as intricate. and of course, like most animation of a certain period, the characters are just a little too static. unless our heroes are walking or operating one of their instruments or something, they stand so ludicrously still that there's something almost Shakespearean in the gesture when they, say, point at something. so if you were hoping for Shatner's trademark histrionics, you shouldn't hold your breath.but for all that a wholehearted effort was made to recapture as much of the original series flavor as they could, and their effort was mostly successful. consider the two finest episodes. in "Yesteryear," Spock revisits his childhood and we learn not only much of what makes him "tick," but a bit more of Vulcan culture as well. it's especially powerful because (possibly for the aforementioned time-slot retraints) this series didn't manage many "character moments."in terms of Trek's approach to psychological and political matter, the high point is "The Magicks Of Megas-Tu." in a move that would be ballsy for any tv series even today, Kirk and crew come to the aid and defense of a character who, it turns out, just might be the person we Earthlings came to know as The Devil. (a simple blueprint for the stories - the William Randolph Hearst to Satan's Charles Foster Kane - rather than a literal Prince Of Darkness, but still, that would make this, as Spock puts it, "the second time Lucifer was cast out, and the first time he was saved.")not every episode reaches that level, of course. there are a few rehashes, as well as a couple prototypes for (more sophisticaled) TNG and Voyager episodes. but there's still a refreshing standard to the series. too often, when a live-action production is transfered to animation, pains are taken to water it down. but it clearly never once occurred to the minds behind this series that (a) only kids would watch it, or (b) said kids would be unable to process the sophistication of the original. (that doesn't even make sense: why the hell would kids even bother with the first series if it eluded their comprehension?) every episode was clearly laid out with an understanding of what the fan's would want and a respect for their intelligence. a given episode may fall a bit flat, but it's never for lack of effort. or passion.and of course let us not forget the reunion of the live-action cast. (well, mostly. for some reason Walter Koening couldn't make it, but to me that's no big deal, as Checkov is probably my least favorite character.) (nothing personal, Walter.) a few even get to shine their brightest here. incidental "guest" characters are mostly played by James "Scotty" Doohan, Nichelle "Uhura" Nichols, and Majel "Chappel" Barret. according to the on-screen triva track, Doohan plays seven characters in "Yesteryear" alone. (who'd of thought that Scotty would turn out to be the Trek equivalent of Mel Blanc?)whether you enjoy this version of Trek or not, it deserves historical recognition for one simple reason: it is the very first concrete demonstration of the fact that the underestimated and ultimately dismissed Star Trek premise would not placidly permit itself to be railroaded into Oblivion. it hadn't even been that long. already, only a handful of years after cancellation, the original Trek (in collusion with the similarly underestimated Gilligan's Island) was establishing once and for all the viability of syndication. history may officially cite the movie series and The Next Generation as playing the most significant role in that revival, but the Saturday morning version was the first stepping-stone in that direction.but again, it's good enough to deserve a bit of consideration on more of a basis than that.
summary: Where No Cartoon Had (As Yet) Gone Before...

reviewText: Not many people (well non-Trekkies of course) know that Star Trek later saw further success as an animated series Saturday mornings on NBC in 1973-75.  Done in what we consider limited or primitive animation today, this highly entertaining series not only lent the voices of Shatner, Nimoy, Kelley, Nichols, Barrett, Doohan, and Takei to the roles they played on the live action version, but was based on stories (some far more imaginative and intelligent) from the regular series' original writers. Just don't expect a degree of high-quality animation we are familiar with today.The original "cels" (celluloid film on which the animated image was drawn and painted) from this series, once available for sale to the general public thru a distributor via Starlog magazine for a mere $19.99, almost 25 years ago are now treasured by Trek collectors and professional animators alike.Long before "Star Trek: The Next Generation," "Voyager," "Deep Space 9, and "Enterprise," and head and shoulders above the typical Saturday fare, this animated series was the first successful spinoff of this legendary sci-fi franchise. Great fun!
summary: Pleasantly surprised with this little known Star Trek animated release!

A couple of years later, I developed an affinity for Star Trek which has lasted through to this day, but it was too late to enjoy ST:TAS as it was then off the air...VCR's were then years away.Despite the rather crude Filmation animation (de rigeur for the day), the stories are quite well-written. Having nearly the entire TOS cast voice the characters is, while totally superfluous and meaningless to the original Sat. morn. crowd, icing on the cake for us trekkies (trekkors/trekkers?). While you can easily tell which aditional characters are being voiced by Majel Barrett, Jimmy Doohan, or Nichele Nichols, they all did a decent job, especially Doohan who voiced 6(!) characters in some episodes!While this set isn't exactly the "fourth" Star Trek season that some portend, it's certainly a worthwhile purchase and worth your valuable leisure time, especially for ST fans and especially at this price. Kudos to Gene Roddenbery and D.C. Fontana for not taking the cheapo easy-way-out by not recycling wholesale ST:TOS plots for ST:TAS (they did recycle certain TOS elements...like the Guardian Of Forever, but in a benign and entertaining way).Highly Recommended!One last word:As alluded to in my review title, the package this set comes in is very cheesy. Yes, I realize it was supposed to be "styled" like the original TOS series DVD "clamshell" boxes. This one is in white plastic, with orange letters and an orange translucent plastic window, shaped like the Starfleet chevron. Inside, a cardboard sleeve holds small stacked clear plastic DVD trays that are taped together, with a small gatefold on the series particulars. I could have done without it...I'll take "regular" DVD boxes instead, Paramount, thank you very much.

reviewText: Star Trek the Animated series is a must-have for die-hard fans of TOS.Its not a kids show. While the plots of a few of the episodes are not quite up to par with classics of TOS (though thankfully none are anywhere near as bad as TOS episode "Spock's Brain"!), the animated series does have several real standout episodes, such as "Mudd's Passion," David Gerrold's "More Tribbles, More Trouble," "Time Trap," and D. C. Fontana's classic "Yesteryear." Having writers from TOS who knew the Trek universe was a smart move. The show deserved the Emmy it won.The animation is generally very good, though it's better in some episodes than in others. Some exterior scenes of the Enterprise and some interior scenes of the bridge are fantastic, but others look rather rushed. It seems that in some episodes painstaking care was taken to exactly duplicate the ship and bridge to the smallest detail, but in others there was more haste and the drawings just aren't as good. Production values were set high, but unfortunately were not always maintained; still, this series surpassed most others of its time. Considering it was produced in the early 70s ('73 and '74),it holds up rather well. And anything occasionally lacking from an artistic/animation standpoint is more than made up for in dialogue. The original cast members (minus Koenig) resuming their roles is great. Doohan, Nichols, Barret and Shatner do a decent job filling in as the voices of the extras.The addition of new species to the crew is welcome, in particular Mr. Arex,  the Edoan navigator who took Checkov's place and was voiced by James Doohan.Some of the new technology doesn't really seem feasible (like the life-support belts), but if you can move beyond this and a few other minor details you should enjoy this series. All-in-all, in spite of some flaws, a neat little series that deserved a bigger budget and a longer run than its two seasons. Thus I give it five stars. This show demonstrated what Saturday morning animated shows could be and set a bar for excellence, that, unfortunately, the network did not maintain. At $45.00 the price is also much more affordable than the other Star Trek series releases by Paramount.I'd  also highly recommend Alan Dean Foster's novelization of this series (similar to James Blish's novelization of the TOS episodes). Foster did an excellent job of fleshing out these 22 half-hour episodes. I believe they've been reprinted by Ballantine.So I'd say beam up a copy of the animated series and go where no man has gone before. Again.
summary: "Boldly Go Where No Man Has Gone Before. Again"

reviewText: Probably unknown to those raised on ST: The Next Generation series, these animated adventures bridged the gulf between the Original Series and the movies that were the "Genesis" of the new wave of Star Trek lore. These are the adventures of the USS Enterprise after the original series left the air, but before the refitting that we see in Star Trek: The Motion Picture.I'm biased perhaps because I grew up on Star Trek and watched each of these episodes over and over again. Superior ones begin with "Yesteryear", one of the finest Star Trek programs ever made. I especially love the mature way it deals with a loss that many children will face when growing up."The Slaver Weapon" gets better and better with each viewing, despite the "pink" ship used by the Kzinti.  It's probably the best Sulu episode since "The Naked Time".  "The Magicks of Megas-Tu" is hokey, but fun hokey with an inspired turn by "Lucien" voiced by James Doohan who, along with Nichelle Nichols did many of the voices during the series. "The Lorelei Signal" has perhaps the most bizzare moment in Star Trek history, Scotty singing an old love song acapella while the Enterprise orbits slowly over a planet.Most of the episodes have monsters or "beasties", probably to appeal to the younger set.  Although "How Sharper than a Serpent's Tooth" is fun for those interested in ancient mythology...or to hear DeForest Kelly say "Capellan Power Cat" with a lot of vim and vigor.There are also three sequels to the Original series episodes.  "Once Upon a Planet" follows up "Shore Leave" and is pretty much an excuse to show another "beastie".  Just like "Mudd's Passion", although it's great that Roger C. Carmel was able to play Harcourt Fenton Mudd one more time.  "More Tribbles, More Troubles" is the best of the three and includes Stanley Adams reprising his role as Cyrano Jones.The presentation of packaging is noteworthy as it's similar to the Orginal Series DVDs. The plastic container is attractive and functional, but you can dispense with it and simply keep the 4 DVD jewel case as I have.All 22 episodes have been remastered, so the quality is very good.  A little too good perhaps as you can see all the scratches and imperfections of the film.  Filmation used a process of moving a still image over the background art and you can certainly see the lines, dust, and scratches. And while some of the characters and in particular the background art is something the original series could never hope to do, Filmation's schedule was so tight that many shots were reused during the series (in particular the Enterprise flying by).The documentary covering the "animated" endevor is both informative, but somewhat disappointing.  I can't believe that no one took a single picture of the actors behind the microphones, especially when they were gathered together for each session. But no pictures are presented during the program. It was nice to include D.C. Fontana, but it was curious that no Star Trek actors like Walter Koenig (who wrote "The Infinate Vulcan") or George Taikai were included.A lot of fuss is made about whether these episodes are "canon" (i.e. should they be considered part of the Star Trek history). I suppose they matter to true "Trekkers", but to me I think if Gene Roddenberry was happy enough to approve them then, I don't see why anyone dissaproves now.I loved these shows when I was growing up and thus I cannot give an unbiased review, but I do dock one star for the extras and in particular the documentary being a disapointment considering the impressive attention payed to the restoration and packaging of these episodes.Tidbits:"Practical Joker" introduces the precuser to the holodeck, a staple of future Star Trek episodes, especially ST:TNG.James T. Kirk has apparently grown some during the interim between the original and animated series.  In "Mudd's Passion", he's just as tall as Harry Mudd, which is somewhat surprising since he's several inches shorter in original series episode "I, Mudd".None of the guest actors are credited, although it's easy to pick them out (like Roger C. Carmel).  But going out on a limb, I believe that William Smithers, who played Captain Merick on the original series "Bread and Circuses" plays the chief investigator in "Albatross".We see during "More Tribbles, More Troubles" the Enterprise able to fire both phasers and photons at the same time, which may not be all that important, but it's pretty cool.Yes, that's Ted Knight (or Ted Baxter to those raised on "The Mary Tyler Moore Show") doing the voice of Carter Winston in "The Survivor".
summary: The Animated Adventures finally gets their due.

reviewText: As a young kid, I was already a big fan of Star Trek TOS when the animated series aired in 1973.I can still remember watching this "cartoon" for the first time on Saturday morning and thinking, gosh how crappy the animation looked!  Maybe I was just too young to appreciate this series when it first aired, or maybe my memory serves me right when I remember how mediocre the animation and stories really were.Fast forward 33 years...I decided to give Star Trek- The Animated Series another try, so I purchased a collection of ten used and very cheap VHS tapes on Ebay. (I payed only ten bucks plus shipping for 20 episodes, so I guess I got a pretty good deal.)  Maybe as an adult I would appreciate this series and enjoy reliving part of my childhood again. Well that's what I was hoping anyway.After watching most of the episodes, I can honestly say that I found a few to be "mildly interesting", and others to be "downright awful!" Overall I would rate this entire series "one big yawn!" I guess it was fun hearing the original crew voices again, but that novelty wore off quickly after just a few episodes.  I think some of the stories could have made good episodes for the live action Star Trek series, but as animation it just didn't work for me.By the early 1970's, and well before the advent of computer assisted animation, the quality of Saturday morning cartoons was going downhill fast. I guess it was just becoming too expensive to produce high quality animation. Unfortunately, Star Trek- The Animated Series was released in this era of cheaply made cartoons, and it shows.  Why they decided to release this "serious" cartoon on Saturday mornings to compete against such kiddie favorites as "Scooby Do" and "Fat Albert" is baffling to me!The series lasted a little over a year and only 22 episodes were produced. It was obviously not a commercial success.Though mediocre animation didn't help the stories, the real problem with this animated series can be summed up in one word- FUN! I love watching Star Trek TOS because it's always fun to watch, and full of exciting action and interesting stories. I also love to watch classic animation for the same reasons, they are fun to watch and they make me laugh!Star Trek- The Animated Series...its no fun and as bad as I remember! I'm so glad I didn't purchase the new DVD set!PS: For those Star Trek "geeks" who are about to write a negative comment just because I didn't agree with your glowing four or five star reviews, I will simply respond to you with the classic Bill Shatner line from Saturday Night Live- "Get a Life!"  We are all entitled to our opinions! :o)

reviewText: The Animated Series, or The Animated Adventures if you prefer a more dramatic title, debuted in 1973 and officially made it to a second season. Twenty-two episodes were drawn and aired on NBC until somebody lost interest or stopped giving Roddenberry money. Those stories are:* "Beyond the Farthest Star* "Yesteryear"* "One of Our Planets is Missing"* "The Lorelei Signal"* "More Tribbles, More Troubles"* "The Survivor"* "The Infinite Vulcan"* "The Magicks of Megas-Tu"* "Once Upon a Planet"* "Mudd's Passion"* "The Terratin Incident"* "The Time Trap"* "The Ambergris Element"* "The Slaver Weapon"* "The Eye of the Beholder"* "The Jihad"* "The Pirates of Orion"* "Bem"* "The Practical Joker"* "Albatross"* "How Sharper Than a Serpent's Tooth"* "The Counter-Clock Incident"Let me just briefly touch on two subjects of note about this series: First, everyone except Chekov "appears" in the series. Walter Koenig did contribute to the series, penning fan favorite "The Infinite Vulcan" (also becoming the first star to write an episode for the franchise). Second, while it is not considered canon, there are many items in the show that have gone on to become canon or semi-fact like Kirk's middle name of Tiberius, the holodeck, tribble predators, Captain April being the first commander of the Enterprise, and so forth. Of course that's no coincidence since the writing pool of the franchise is a touch on the shallow side.TAS often refers back to The Original Series. Simply looking at the titles gives you tribbles and Harry Mudd. But beyond that, there are continual references to the original 79 episodes. From one point of view, it's nice to show such strong continuity; on the other hand, it showed a lack of imagination seemingly so firmly tied to those tales. While "Shore Leave" was interesting the first time around--but has since been trumped by the planet Risa (in every subsequent series including Enterprise!)--did we need to go back to this planet?Granted, the show did try many new ideas, working to continue to explore strange new worlds; sadly, many of these ideas failed for a variety of reasons. For example, the exploration of the center of the universe ("The Magicks of Megas-Tu") was boring and fell flat, new characters M'Ress and Arex were treated too casually without explanation, and some concepts were interesting but never fully developed (like Uhura taking command of the Enterprise in "The Lorelei Signal").The vast majority of these stories are exceptionally dull and uninspired. Even Roddenberry confessed that this show was done just for the money. With that at the heart of this creation, it's hard to make a truly good show. And they didn't. But what specifically is wrong with the series? Just about everything:* Weak Stories: It's never a good thing when a 23-minute story puts you to sleep at 7:30 in the evening. "The Magicks of Megas-Tu" truly did put me to sleep that early, and as it's on disc two (of four) I found it hard to muster up the strength to want to go back and keep watching. Not all of the stories are that bad, but even the best ones ("Yesteryear," "The Time Trap") in the series are merely average.* Out of Character: It's not like there weren't 79 episodes to refer to when writing these new stories, so how is it that all of the characters are all a bit off? Kirk is not as aggressively and heroically confident as he should be, Spock is often far too emotional, and McCoy is simply far too pessimistic and unsympathetic. I often wondered why Deforest recited his lines because they were so terribly against his established character. It's hard to invest in a show when its characters are wrong.* Bad Voice Acting: Though the bonus features state everyone came in and recorded together (at least once), it doesn't come across that way. Instead of interacting as a chorus, it sounds like a bunch of soloists. I don't recall anyone talking over anyone else; it was Kirk speaks then Spock speaks then McCoy speaks then Uhura speaks and so on. There wasn't any interaction between the characters, and that made it all feel like line recitation. Bolstering that was the voice acting itself, which was clearly uninspired and done without any emotion (and we're talking about more than just Spock). There was no passion, no true intent, or no force behind the words. The actors didn't seem to be in the role, perhaps because they couldn't visualize what was going on. It's a true skill to be a talented voice actor, and no one in this show excelled.* Limited Voices: How many voices did Majel Barrett have to do? What about Nichelle Nichols? James Doohan? George Takei? No matter how they tried to disguise their voices, you could always tell it was Majel, Nichelle, or George (but Jimmy was good with the voices, at least). Hire some more people so you have some depth and variety in your ensemble. Hearing George pretending to be a Klingon just ruins the moment.* Average Animation: Though there was no 3-D animation in the early 70s, this batch of 2-D is pretty average. No attempt was made to flesh out the details and create lush environments. Many shortcuts were taken to (what I presume) get the episodes finished. For example, I like to see my characters when they are running instead of black silhouettes of the character. Or, wouldn't it be nice to clean up the "matte lines" and dirt around the Enterprise as it goes through space? Shoddy, lazy animation just doesn't stand up to the test of time.Moving on to the discs themselves, the packaging is great. Be warned, however, that the discs fit tightly inside the clamshell and any slight alteration can cause damage to the cardboard cover around the discs. The video and audio transfers are unspectacular. The video is clean with acceptable colors and detail (as it is). I didn't notice any transfer errors across the presentation. The audio does offer an interesting diversion by including the original mono mix and a new 5.1 Dolby mix. It came across very thin and hollow. Going to the original mono track afforded a richer, truer sound. And if you think the 5.1 will offer some semblance of surround sound, you would be incorrect.This set does offer a nice assortment of bonus features, even though you may not at first notice them. The problem is that the discs don't have a special feature button. You have to go into each episode (or read the DVD labels) to see if it has any related bonus material. You'll miss all this if you use the available "play all" episode option. Included are:* Audio Commentaries:"More Tribbles, More Troubles"--David Gerrold, writer"Bem"--David Gerrold"How Sharper Than a Serpent's Tooth"--David Wise, writer* Text Commentaries by Michael and Denise Okuda:"Yesteryear""The Eye of the Beholder""The Counter-Clock Incident"* Storyboard Gallery on "The Infinite Vulcan"On the final disc are some "stand-alone" bonus items:* "Drawn to the Final Frontier: The Making of Star Trek: The Animated Series" (24 minutes) is a good, overall review of the show, helping to properly place it in the franchise--albeit it with a bit too much self-congratulation.* "What's the Star Trek Connection?" (5.75 minutes, broken down into 11 segments) shows ideas and characters and how they connect to the other shows in the franchise. It's too simple a summation.* "Show History" is a text-based, quick and dirty rundown of the supporting characters voice work. You'll learn nothing.We've had to wait too long for this series! Not limited by what you could practically do, the freedom of animation truly allowed the Enterprise to achieve the grandest of adventures. Exploring parallel universes, the center of the universe, miniaturized people, and supersized tribbles took the franchise to a big new frontier. Everything you ever wanted to see in The Classic Series is wonderfully realized in The Animated Series. The five-year mission has been completed, filling us with a sense of awe.I will admit to a moment of excitement when I realized that this was Star Trek that I had never seen before. This was my last chance at seeing "new" episodes for who knows how many years. It is animated, but still "Trek," but then I watched it...It's true that The Animated Series has its moments and puts forth some interesting ideas, locales, and characters. But, in the grand scheme, it just doesn't work and doesn't quite fit with the established work of The Original Series.In the end, I found myself thoroughly unimpressed with this series. As a result, I am not recommending this set except for those who have already seen the show and found something to like. For the casually curious, just pretend this one doesn't exist. That's what Roddenberry did when he bestowed official non-canon status.Star Trek: The Animated Series is hereby found guilty of being a poor marksman and missing the mark.

reviewText: I cannot add anything else to all the views that have gone before except my personal feelings for this series. It is difficult to describe the significance of this series to Star Trek fans when it came out in '73 and '74. Back then there was almost nothing new in the way of stories or merchandise available (except perhaps for a few comic books.) This series filled a real vacuum. More than that, it was actually faithful to the original (much more than the original movie.) Given the attitude and low budgets for animation in the 70's an animated Star Trek could easily have been a horrible embarrassment, but thankfully it was not. If anything it was actually better in some ways than the original live-action show. In fact, I would have been satisfied with only this series if there had never been another Trek series or movie made. As far as I was concerned these two seasons brought closure to the original five-year mission. Too bad that there wasn't at least a little more. It is a treat being able to watch them again at a reasonable price.

reviewText: I am not going to go into details about what stories are in this series or what I like or don't like about the packaging as I am sure you have read it all in the many other reviews.What I will say, is that as one who loves to collect old television as well as animated series, I think this is one of the best Saturday shows ever released on television. reviewText: After the original series ended its three-year run in 1969, Trek fans assumed that they had seen the last of the adventures of the starship Enterprise and her crew.  However, their weekly "fix" was satisfied when NBC and Paramount produced a Saturday morning animated version in 1973, featuring voices from all but one of the original cast members.  Not only did the new show feature those voices, some of the same talented writers from the first show were hired to pen new exploits for Kirk and company.And what a set of stories did they provide for the shortlived series.Making a drastic departure from the usual Saturday morning "kiddie" fare, the stories on the 'toon Trek featured primetime-like adult storytelling, tackling such issues as holy wars ("Jihad"), cloning ("The Infinite Vulcan"), weapons of war and their aftermath ("The Slaver Weapon"), legends of alien visitations to primitive Earth peoples ("How Sharper Than a Serpent's Tooth"), and rites of passage (the award-winning "Yesteryear").Also, the series may have paved the way for the big-budgeted first feature film in that the show's "One of our Planets is Missing" bears a striking similarity with the 1979 Robert Wise film.Homage is paid to the original by featuring guest vocal work for actors that portrayed memorable characters in the original series: Mark Lenard (Sarek in "Yesteryear"), Roger C. Carmel (Harry Mudd in "Mudd's Passion), and Stanley Adams (Cyrano Jones in "More Tribbles, More Troubles"). A pre-"Mary Tyler Moore Show" Ted Knight is the featured guest performer in the episode "The Survivor," another entry that would parallel a later "Next Generation" installment.Also, the series allowed cast members James Doohan, George Takei, Nichelle Nichols, and Majel Barrett a chance to show their acting versatility as they not only provided the voices for the characters of Scotty, Sulu, Uhura, and Nurse Chapel, respectively, the quartet assayed several of the respective voices of guest characters, written and animated specifically for individual episodes.Animation, as producer Hal Sutherland says in the featured "making of" documentary, allowed the show's writers to place the Enterprise in settings/situations that were budgetarily impossible for the original series.Thus, animation really allowed the crew to "boldly go" where no other Trek had been...at the time.

reviewText: Back during the '70s, there was a trend to "adapt" popular prime-time television episodes into Saturday morning "kid" versions.  This included "Emergency," (Saturday morning version - "Emergency Plus 4") "Lassie," ("Lassie's Rescue Rangers"), and I even think there was a short-lived version of "Adam-12" and "Dragnet" (these shows, as well as "Emergency" were produced in prime-time by Jack Webb's Mark IV studios).  Most of these were produced by Filmation Studios, which were famous for both animated ("The Archies," "The Hardy Boys," "Fantastic Voyage," "Journey To The Center Of The Earth," and various DC Comics heroes) and live-action ("Ark 2," "Space Academy," "Jason Of Star Command," and "Shazam! - The Original Captain Marvel")  Anything that Filmation had their own control over tended to be high-quality storywise (namely the live-action series, and the open-copyrighted animated ones) - everything else was micromanaged by the same people who actually owned the copyrights, as they are won't to do.  Those that were controlled by others had a tendancy to show the results of being overmanaged.  This wasn't the case in "Star Trek."In fact, Filmation and NBC Daytime took the rather unusual approach to secure the permission and production ideas from Gene Roddenberry.  This included hiring folks, at Gene's behest, who had worked in writing, directing, and producing the original series, and even using much of "Star Trek's" production bible as source material.  This went far beyond what was usual at that time - simply hiring the original actors to provide voice work.  What ended up being aired was, for all intents and purposes, the fourth season "Star Trek" would've had if it wasn't cancelled first.There are some who don't recognize the animated series as "official."  This is understandable, as Gene Roddenberry himself said it wasn't.  However, when one takes an objective look at how the animated version was produced, who was involved, and the overall quality that went into the stories, it can't be argued that this was what would've been on-air if the live-action show continued.  Others call the animation crude, save for what was rotoscoped.  You have to remember, however, that this WAS the standard for the times.  TV animation, even beloved icons like "The Flintstones," had to be crude to come in on time for each week and on budget.  Finally, there are little bits of established facts, such as Amanda, Spock's mother, having the last name of "Grayson," Kirk's middle name being Tiberius, even the existence of the Next Generation's holodeck, being backdoored into official cannon that had their first appearance in the animated show.In short, I consider it canon.  And good television to boot.

reviewText: There has been alot of heated debate over the years by trekkies as to whether The Animated Series fits into the Trek timeline, or even, if it can be considered a valid part of the Star Trek canon. I fondly remember viewing Star Trek: The Animated Series on cable television for the first time some years ago, and to be honest, I didn't really know what to think. For one thing the overall production value is quite low; and the episodes with their simplified stories are squarely aimed at a younger, mostly preteen audience. However there are some important factors that need to be taken into consideration when watching The Animated Series, such as...* Several of this shows better episodes were originally written for Star Trek: The Original Series by some of its veteran scriptwriters, and that were later adapted to fit the format of The Animated Series.* All of The Original Series cast voiced their respective characters, with the sole exception of Walter Koenig's role as Chekov, although he did contribute the moving script for "The Infinite Vulcan" episode.* Many ideas presented in The Animated Series were incorporated into later Star Trek productions as established fact; like for example the middle name of Captain Kirk being Tiberius, it even had an early version of the holodeck!* Star Treks creator Gene Roddenberry also gave the show his cautious endorsement and it is firmly set in his fictional universe; with its secular, idealistic and tolerant vision of humanities future. What else can one ask for?So on recently purchasing the DVD boxed set of The Animated Series I freely admit I've had a change of heart about this underrated show, it is part of the Star Trek legacy. For some people the rather dated animated format might take awhile to get used to, but if you believe in the progressive ethos that Star Trek espouses, you should be able to look beyond this limitation. The use of animation gave the producers a relatively free reign to introduce bizarre new life forms and aliens to the Star Trek universe that don't look even remotely humanoid, such as the three armed character of Lieutenant Arex. The Animated Series also included more ships and gadgets that would have been far too costly to build as models or props for a live action series at the time, with two such examples being the Starfleet Aquashuttle or Cargo Drones. Filmation who was responsible for The Animated Series production were also not constrained by the size of a sound stage or low budget when it came to designing the sets, or even strange and exotic new worlds. Sure the animation is relatively crude, the incidental music repetitive, and the voice acting wooden, but it still has a funky campiness to it that I find most entertaining. The Animated Series should also be viewed in the context of the era it was made in, the groovy early 1970s when daytime cartoons made for television were fairly cheap to make. Yet in the end the stories are what truly count, and there are several unexpectedly intelligent episodes in this often overlooked series that give one much appreciated food for thought.The white plastic box that the four DVDs come is as usual with the various Star Trek packaging, very cool and tasteful; being ergonomically designed, aesthetically pleasing and easy to handle. When it comes to the transfer quality the show itself is exceptionally clear, though I do believe The Animated Series special features are a little too meager. I felt there could have been rather more; and think that for some reason CBS/Paramount didn't consider it worth their while to include any more extras in this boxed set, which is such a shame. So while it may not be as good as the more well known live action Star Trek series, it does have a unique place in the until recently ever expanding Star Trek universe. Don't expect too much from Star Trek: The Animated Series; just sit back, chill out and enjoy it for what it's worth, and then you can make up your own mind. Beam me up Scotty!

reviewText: For those of us who grew up in the 70's the animated "Star Trek" adventures was an enjoyable and well written series. Although the animation was limited and extremely inconsistent the production design is imaginative accurately capturing the look of the original live action series.Although the episodes themselves appear "rushed" (they clearly could have used more time for exposition, story and character development but were hampered by their 22 minute running time)without the strong resolution in many instances one would have hoped for overall the writing is quite strong particularly when compared to the shows on Saturday morning at the time. Where else would you find an episode that deals with how we handle death ("Yesteryear") at that time? The actors clearly aren't as comfortable doing the animated series as the live action--how else to explain the flat emotional feel of the performances? Clearly the show didn't have time to develop the background that the hour long drama did which would explain why D.C.Fontana and the other writers would bring back fan favorites (less backstory to explain allowing more time for this new adventure).The presentation looks extremely good, very clean looking with occasional hints of dust and dirt that were probably there on the original cels. The advantage of working in animation here is that we see creatures on the show that the series would not have been able to show as a live action series (today they could of course with CGI). The animation isn't any better or worse than you might find on a web animated show today.We get three text commentaries from Michael and Denise Okuda and three audio commentaries two from writer David Gerrold on "More Tribbles, More Troubles" & "BEM" and one from writer David Wise on "How Sharper Than a Serpent's Tooth". There is also a storyboard gallery for "The Infinite Vulcan" as well as a featurette on the series.Gerrold discusses how "More Tribbles, More Troubles" was developed for the third season of the original live action series. He provides a terrific commentary and is honest about both the limitations of the series and the advantages of the show. Gerrold gives Fontana a lot of credit for mentoring him when he wrote his first script for "Star Trek" back in 1967. Producer Fred Freiberg didn't like the humor of "The Trouble with Tribbles" episode and shot it down even though Roddenberry had told Gerrold that he would be doing a third season "Tribbles" episode. Dorothy Fontana as associate producer of the animated series contacted Gerrold to come on board and revise his script for the animated show.Dorothy Fontana, David Gerrold, producer Lou Scheimer, director Hal Sutherland and others appear in the featurette "Drawn to the Final Frontier" discussing how the show was pitched and produced for NBC. Scheimer approached Roddenberry about contacting Paramount and arranging for Filmation to do the show for NBC. Gerrold points out that much of the more adult orientation of the stories was due to Scheimer wanting to tell entertaining and great stories within a half hour. Director Sutherland discusses putting the show together and the difficulties/challenges of working with the material."What's the Star Trek Connection?" allows you to select various themes, characters, etc. that appeared throughout the "Trek" universe. "Show History" is a brief text section that discusses the origin of the show.The design of the box is a variation on the original series boxed sets but more compact (there's 22 24 minute episodes so the entire first season and the handful of episodes held over for the next season are all on four DVDs along with the bonus features). There's a little booklet like with the other sets with a synopsis of each episode and a bit of background on the series.Overall the writing is pretty good on the show with the late Samuel Peeples ("Where No Man Has Gone Before"), D.C. Fontana ("Tomorrow Is Yesterday"), David Gerrold ("The Trouble with Tribles")actor Walter Koenig, science fiction writer Larry Niven and others contributing scripts to the show. While it lacks the drama and humor of the live action series (and sometimes melodrama) the show is far more adult than other shows from the time.A very good series that managed to over come its limitations and use the animation format to its advantage with a talented writing-production staff that did an amazing job considering the resources they had to work with at the time. Fans that saw this when they were kids will be pleased as will "Trek" fans.
summary: Nice looking presentation of the animated series with commentary tracks and extras

reviewText: No collection of Filmation cartoons is complete without their version of Star Trek.  Like many Filmation projects from the seventies through the early eighties, the emphasis was on creating "realistic" animation focusing on well-drawn characters with live-action sounding voice acting.  Of these projects, Star Trek is one of the best, right up there with their version the Adam West-Burt Ward Batman show, the Flash Gordon series from 1978 and their William Conrad Lone Ranger series from 1980 (I also love their classic Superman - the show the company was founded to produce - and Justice League cartoons from the sixties, but Filmation was still not as refined an animation house in those days, and their classic Zorro 'toons were really farmed out to Japan, so they don't count as real Filmation shows).Of course, Filmation is known for their repeated use of stock animation that was reassembled to tell many different stories.  This is something that bugs a certain group of fans, but I prefer to look at the creativity behind manipulating the stock footage into new stories in creative ways, with some doctoring for specific story scenarios.  On Star Trek it worked particularly well because they were emulating a TV show that used a set number of stock effects shots repeatedly anyway (Enterprise in orbit, the one long ship-length shot of the Enterprise from it's side, etc).  These techniques allowed Filmation to be the last bastion of TV animation in the United States, and I find the feel of old Filmation cartoons to be very endearing.
